body:
The example that's listed here isn't very helpful. 
https://github.com/grpc/grpc.github.io/blob/master/docs/tutorials/basic/ruby.md


> def route_chat(notes)
>   q = EnumeratorQueue.new(self)
>   t = Thread.new do
>     begin
>       notes.each do |n|
>       	...
>     end
>       end
>   q = EnumeratorQueue.new(self)
> ...
>   return q.each_item
> end

Probably the most basic thing to know about the streaming call API is just that the parameter is a ruby `Enumerable` of the request proto object (`WatchRequest` in your example) , and that the response is also a ruby `Enumerable` (of the response proto object, `WatchResponse` in your example).

So e.g., the most basic bidi stream (without interleaved messages), might send an array of the input request object types, and expect an enumerable of them in return (this working would depend on the service method implementation of course).

With more custom enumerable types, as in the route guide example, one could do interleaved messages in whatever way is needed, if that makes sense.

As for `GRPC::Core::CallError: grpc_call_start_batch failed with outstanding read or write present (code=8)`, this looks like a sort of internal error and seems strange, it might be interesting of there's a code snippet that causes this.

Here is the code I am working with...

Using the etcdv3 gem.
```
require 'etcdv3`
```

Stubs Watch Command
```
stub = Etcdserverpb::Watch::Stub.new('localhost:2379', :this_channel_is_insecure, timeout: 10)
```
Defines key we are going to listen on.
```
create_req = Etcdserverpb::WatchCreateRequest.new(key: 'key', progress_notify: true)
watch_req = Etcdserverpb::WatchRequest.new(create_request: create_req)
```
This generates an enumerable.
```
enum = stub.watch(watch_req)
<Enumerator: #<GRPC::BidiCall:0x007fc47a13a9e8 @call=#<GRPC::Core::Call:0x007fc47a13acb8>, @marshal=#<Proc:0x007fc479bb3128@/Users/shaun/.rbenv/versions/2.2.4/lib/ruby/gems/2.2.0/gems/grpc-1.2.0-universal-darwin/src/ruby/lib/grpc/generic/rpc_desc.rb:50>, @op_notifier=nil, @unmarshal=#<Proc:0x007fc479bb3010@/Users/shaun/.rbenv/versions/2.2.4/lib/ruby/gems/2.2.0/gems/grpc-1.2.0-universal-darwin/src/ruby/lib/grpc/generic/rpc_desc.rb:62>, @metadata_received=false, @reads_complete=false, @writes_complete=true, @complete=false, @done_mutex=#<Mutex:0x007fc47a13a998>, @req_view=nil, @enq_th=#<Thread:0x007fc47a13a970@/Users/shaun/.rbenv/versions/2.2.4/lib/ruby/gems/2.2.0/gems/grpc-1.2.0-universal-darwin/src/ruby/lib/grpc/generic/bidi_call.rb:84 dead>>:read_loop({:is_client=>true})>
```

The enum exposes commands like `each` `each_with_object` etc.  and when I run the following command it will block until the timeout is hit.
`enum.each{|e| puts  e.inspect }`

Either I am not properly generating events, or I am misunderstanding how I am supposed to capture streamed responses.  

Random note:  If I try and rerun `enum.each{|e| puts e.inspect }` I get.

`GRPC::Core::CallError: grpc_call_start_batch failed with outstanding read or write present (code=8)` 

Any thoughts?

Grpc logs during the blocked event. 


off the bat it looks like the deadline of 10 (in seconds) is happening.

But IIC the undesired behavior here is the 
`GRPC::Core::CallError: grpc_call_start_batch failed with outstanding read or write present (code=8)`?

If instead of 
```
enum = stub.watch(watch_req)
enum.each { |e| puts e.inspect }
```

you do:
```
stub.watch(watch_req) { |e| puts e.inspect }
```

does the problem go away?
<s> - if so, I think this might be hitting a bug in client-side streaming repsonse exception (probably should see a `GRPC::DeadlineExceeded` exception)</s>
scratched my above comment as I can't say that's the cause right now, though still the `GRPC::DeadlineExceeded` I think should be showing up here.

To repro attempt I started an etcd server (latest release) locally as per https://github.com/coreos/etcd/releases/.

I tried to repro with:

```
require 'etcdv3'

def main
  stub = Etcdserverpb::Watch::Stub.new('localhost:2379', :this_channel_is_insecure, timeout: 10)

  create_req = Etcdserverpb::WatchCreateRequest.new(key: 'key', progress_notify: true)
  watch_req = Etcdserverpb::WatchRequest.new(create_request: create_req)

  enum = stub.watch(watch_req)
  enum.each { |e| puts e.inspect }
end

main
```

and got a `(GRPC::DeadlineExceeded)` exception as expected.

If the enumerable response stream is attempted to be reused though, like:

```
require 'etcdv3'

def main
  stub = Etcdserverpb::Watch::Stub.new('localhost:2379', :this_channel_is_insecure, timeout: 10)

  create_req = Etcdserverpb::WatchCreateRequest.new(key: 'key', progress_notify: true)
  watch_req = Etcdserverpb::WatchRequest.new(create_request: create_req)

  enum = stub.watch(watch_req)
  enum.each { |e| puts e.inspect }
rescue
  enum.each { |e| puts e.inspect }
end

main
```

the error thrown is `GRPC::Core::CallError: grpc_call_start_batch failed with outstanding read or write present (code=8)`, as mentioned here.

But I'm not completely sure what the problem posted here is about, is it the raising of `CallError`?

@apolcyn  The end goal is to figure out how capture and act on response events.  The CallErrors with the exception of `GRPC::DeadlineExceeded` are just adding additional confusion on my adventure to figuring out how to make sense of this.

Response events should be generated whenever there's a change on the `key` namespace (which is defined in the WatchCreateRequest), however no matter what I do here, I can't seem to capture or output the response events. 

For reference:  A change on the `key` namespace could be done by.
```
conn = Etcdv3.new(url: 'http://localhost:2379')
conn.put('key', 'somevalue')
```

I appreciate your help here!

It looks like there is a simple fix to the code here:
We should just change 

```
enum = stub.watch(watch_req)
```

to 

```
enum = stub.watch([watch_req])
```

(since it's a bidi call, the input parameter needs to be an enumerable, representing the "stream", of the request type).

But this looks like a grpc-ruby problem in that the exception  for this bad type isn't surfacing. For bidi calls in grpc-ruby, currently there is a separate "write loop" thread that iterates through the request enumerable and sends them. That write loop thread is failing when the input type is bad, but the exception doesn't raise in an obvious way.

Omg ... Thank you ... 

I am very happy and slightly frustrated that it was that simple of a fix. ðŸ˜† 

I appreciate your help :)  I can now finish up the etcd v3 binding now. :)
Thanks for posting as this brings up the lacking exception issue, leaving this open with https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/10636 to fix
